questions.text: A 33-year-old female with one child underwent suction and evacuation of a complete hydatiform mole which was confirmed by histology. Her serum b-hcg level is still elevated after 7 weeks of evacuation. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Single dose im methotrexate. In the given question, the female is at risk for the development of GTN following the evacuation of molar pregnancy. It prevents uterine invasion or metastasis. Hence in this patient, we need to start prophylactic chemotherapy

Highyeild:

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia: Introduction: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia includes invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor. Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia almost always develops with or follows some form of pregnancy The features which define at-risk women are- Age of patient > 35 years. Initial levels of serum hCG 100,000 IU/mL. hCG level fails to become normal by 7–9 weeks time or there is re-elevation. Histologically diagnosed as an infiltrative mole. Evidence of metastases irrespective of the level of hCG. Previous history of a molar pregnancy. A woman who is unreliable for follow-up. In this patient, we need to start prophylactic chemotherapy. Criteria for diagnosis of postmolar gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. When 4 consecutive hCG values are plateau D₁, D,, D1, D2, (± 10% of previous value) 3 consecutive hCG values are rising (> 10% of previous value) D₁, D,, D14 B-hCG level remains above normal even after 6 months of evacuation Criteria for diagnosis of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia Histological criteria for choriocarcinoma sfree.com

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Multiagent combination chemotherapy is given in case of poor prognosis or high-risk metastatic tumor. Option: C - repeat suction and evacuation are not required in this case. Option: D - hysterectomy indications are different compared to indications of prophylactic chemotherapy for at-risk women for the development of GTN.

Extraedge:

Choriocarcinoma M/C develops after–molar pregnancy. High-risk choriocarcinoma develops after = full-term pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32 year old female with normal delivery of her 4th baby now presents with intractable vaginal bleeding. She is persistently not feeling well. Her B-HCG levels are also increasing. She also complained of cough, breathlessness, and hemoptysis. She was admitted to the ward for further management. What is the FIGO staging of the tumor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stage III In the given question, the patient after termination of molar pregnancy and treatment with suction and evacuation presented with intractable vaginal bleeding, persistent ill health, and features of lung metastasis like cough, breathlessness, and hemoptysis. Hence, the FIGO stage will be stage III.

Highyeild:

Clinical features of GTN : Patients present with continuous bleeding P/V even after evacuation. Uterine subinvolution. Invasive moles can lead to myometrium perforation and intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Persistence of theca lutein cysts. Metastasis- In choriocarcinoma M/C site of metastasis is the lungs FIGO staging for GTT is given below- rewrite it FIGO anatomic staging for GTT Stage I The lesion is confined to the uterus. Stage II The lesion spreads outside the uterus but within pelvis Stage III The lesion metastasizes to the lungs. Stage IV The lesion metastasizes to sites such as brain, liver or gastrointestinal tract. ree.co Options A, B, and D: are incorrect options.

questions.text: A 21-year-old with 12 weeks of amenorrhea presents with lower abdomen pain and passage of grape-like vesicular discharge from the vagina. On P/A examination her uterus felt like Duffy, with height corresponding to 14 weeks. B-HCG level was found to be > 25,000miu/l. on doing USG following finding was noted. What is the diagnosis for the case when the same finding is noted on the chest x-ray?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Choriocarcinoma In the given clinical scenario, the patient is having features of hydatidiform mole like – lower abdominal pain, and vesicular discharge from the vagina. B-HCG level is more than 25,000. The uterus is felt elastic(Duffy) , and its height is greater than the period of gestation. On USG, the following image given shows a snowstorm appearance . The questions ask about the condition in which a similar appearance is shown on a chest x-ray, hence the answer is choriocarcinoma.

Highyeild:

CHORIOCARCINOMA Most malignant tumor of uterus. MC mode of spread is hematogenous Most common sites of metastases in choriocarcinoma are : Lung (80%) > Vagina (30%) > Pelvis (20%) > Liver (10%) and Brain (10%) mebo Symptoms: Mostly presents as irregular bleeding or uterine hemorrhage following an abortion, a molar p or a normal delivery. Moksfree. Metastasis Lung Metastasis It is seen in 80% cases Patient presents with respiratory symptoms like dyspnoea, hemoptysis, chest pain, On X-ray it may produce the following four patterns: An alveolar snow storm pattern? (Remember snowstorm appearance on USG- means H mole; snowstorm appearance on chest X-ray- means choriocarcinoma) occlusionboorte mebook - Discrete rounded densities or canon ball appearance - Pleural effusion? An embolic pattern caused by pulmonary arterial Vaginal Metastasis It is seen in 30% cases Metastasis occurs in suburethra or in fornices? Metastasis appears as purple hemorrhagic projections which are highly vascular and bleed on touch (pathognomic of choriocarcinoma) Tumor Markers Tumor marker for choriocarcinoma: B-hCG

questions.text: A P4 38-year-old female in her previous pregnancy (6 months back) presented with 9 weeks of amenorrhea with pain lower abdomen and the following finding on P/V. Her B-HCG levels were also raised to normal pregnancy. After the definitive treatment also, she complained of persistent ill health and intractable vaginal bleeding. There are no other symptoms of breathlessness, headache, convulsions, or paralysis. Which of the following is the definitive management of the given condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Cervical dilatation followed by suction and evacuation.

options.label: D
options.text: Only routine follow-up and supportive therapy.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hysterectomy In the given clinical scenario, an elderly multipara female with complaints of intractable bleeding and persistent ill health despite definitive treatment i.e. suction and evacuation for the last molar pregnancy as given in the question.(i.e 9 weeks of amenorrhea with pain lower abdomen, raised B-HCG level ). Hence this becomes the case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasi a. In this female, as she is approaching her 40s and also completed her famil y with intractable vaginal bleeding, the definitive management will be a hysterectomy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - Suction and evacuation are done in case of molar pregnancy with the passage of a grape-like vesicle from the vagina. It is done along with supportive therapy for anemia and infection and regular follow-up. Option: B - Cervical dilatation followed by suction and evacuation is done in case the os is closed indicated by no passage of vaginal discharge or grape-like vesicle. Option: D: no role of conservative management here .

questions.text: A 34 year old P3 female after being diagnosed with PSTT was treated definitively and then was on regular follow-up by monitoring serial s.hPL level. What is the definitive treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hysterectomy In the given question, as the patient is suffering form PSTT, the definitive treatment is hysterectomy as these tumors are chemoresistant.

Highyeild:

PLACENTAL SITE TROPHOBLASTIC TUMOR (PSTT) Characteristics of PSTT The tumor arises from the intermediate trophoblasts of the placental bed and is composed mainly of cytotrophoblastic cells. These tumors have been associated with modestly elevated serum ẞ-hCG levels but they produce variant forms of B-hCG . In these tumors identification of a high proportion of free ẞ-hCG (>30%) is considered diagnostic. hPL (human placental lactogen) is also a tumor marker for these tumors. The patient presents with vaginal bleeding. Local invasion into the myometrium and lymphatics occurs. PSTT is not responsive to chemotherapy. Hysterectomy is the preferred treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - Single-dose chemotherapy is used for choriocarcinoma patients with non-metastatic or low-risk patients. Option: B - Multidose chemotherapy is used for high-risk or metastatic choriocarcinoma patients. Option: D - suction and evacuation- it is used in patients with hydatidiform mole . Hence it is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman complains of irregular bleeding for 7 months after the delivery of her 5th baby. Curettage is performed and histology reveals a choriocarcinoma. Her serum B-HCG level is 2*10^5 IU/L. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Give multiagent chemotherapy In the given question, to decide the treatment option we have to calculate the WHO prognostic score for GTD. In this patient- Antecedent normal pregnancy- 2 Age 41 years- 1 Pregnancy 7 months ago-2 Serum HCG level 2*10^5IU/L. – 2 Hence, the prognostic score for this patient will be 7 which includes her being at high risk.

Highyeild:

The given image shows the scoring system- Parameter 0 1 2 3 Age (y) < 40 ≥40 — — Antecedent pregnancy Mole Abortion Term — Interval in months from index pregnancy and chemotherapy started within <4 months 4-6 months 7-12 months > 12 months Pretreatment ẞ-hCG level < 10 ^ 3 10 ^ 3 - 10 ^ 4 10 ^ 4 - 10 ^ 5 > 10 ^ 5 ABO group (female x male) O or A, A or AB Largest tumor (cm) <3 3-4 cm >= 5 Site of metastases Lungs Spleen, kidney Gastrointestinal Brain, Liver Number of metastases — 1-4 4-8 >8 meb Prior chemotherapy Total score: — — >2 Patients having a score of 6 or less are considered as having low risk or good prognosis and patient having a score of 7 or more are considered as having high risk or good prognosis. In general a patient belonging to good prognosis or low risk group (score 0-6) means that they can be treated by a single agent chemotherapy which is usually successful in them, whereas a patient belonging to poor prognosis/ high risk group (score >7) respond badly to chemotherapy and require prolonged hospitalization with multiple courses of chemotherapy.
